text: I really like the tone out of betfair lately. Outside of the occasional ban without warning, most of the steps they are taking are supportive of pro / tech savvy gamblers/ exchange eco system. They seem happy monetising via premium charge and let the best modelling / tech win.

elements.text: I really like the tone out of betfair lately. Outside of the occasional ban without warning, most of the steps they are taking are supportive of pro / tech savvy gamblers/ exchange eco system. They seem happy monetising via premium charge and let the best modelling / tech win.

text: <https://github.com/liampauling/betfair/blob/master/examples/exampleinplayservice.py|https://github.com/liampauling/betfair/blob/master/examples/exampleinplayservice.py>

attachments.text:
```
import logging

import betfairlightweight

"""
inplayservice is the API endpoint that the website uses to
provide scores data, scores provides a snapshot whereas event
timeline will give update details.
"""

# setup logging
logging.basicConfig(level=<http://logging.INFO|logging.INFO>)  # change to DEBUG to see log all updates

# create trading instance
trading = betfairlightweight.APIClient("username", "password", app_key="appKey")

# login
trading.login()

# update
event_ids = [28369618]

# score request (provide list / returns list)
scores = trading.in_play_service.get_scores(event_ids=event_ids)
print(scores)
for score in scores:
    print(
        score,
        score.description,
        score.status,
        "%s-%s" % (score.score.home.score, score.score.away.score),
    )  # view resources or debug to see all values available


# timeline request (single)
timeline = trading.in_play_service.get_event_timeline(event_id=event_ids[0])
print(timeline)
for update in timeline.update_detail:
    print(
        update.update_id, update.elapsed_regular_time, update.type, update.update_time
    )  # view resources or debug to see all values available


# timelines request (provide list / returns list)
timelines = trading.in_play_service.get_event_timelines(event_ids=event_ids)
print(timelines)
for timeline in timelines:
    for update in timeline.update_detail:
        print(
            update.update_id,
            update.elapsed_regular_time,
            update.type,
            update.update_time,
        )  # view resources or debug to see all values available

```

text:
Hey everyone, got another noob question -  Looks like I'm getting prices/odds through trading.betting.list_market_book() that are off from what I can see directly on Betfair's website. Generally it seems that these prices are better than those on the website. For instance, I might get 5.6 to back when I'm seeting 5.3 on the website. This is for in-game football matches, if that makes a difference.
Is this at all possible or should I be digging into/debugging my code?

elements.text:
Hey everyone, got another noob question -  Looks like I'm getting prices/odds through trading.betting.list_market_book() that are off from what I can see directly on Betfair's website. Generally it seems that these prices are better than those on the website. For instance, I might get 5.6 to back when I'm seeting 5.3 on the website. This is for in-game football matches, if that makes a difference.
Is this at all possible or should I be digging into/debugging my code?

text:
1) Are you logged into the website?
2) Have you requested virtual prices from the API?

elements.text:
1) Are you logged into the website?
2) Have you requested virtual prices from the API?

text: 3) What are your refresh rate settings on the website?

elements.text: 3) What are your refresh rate settings on the website?

text: 4) There’s also “Bet View” on the website that bunches up small size prices to the least competitive with a total over some threshold (I think default £2)

elements.text: 4) There’s also “Bet View” on the website that bunches up small size prices to the least competitive with a total over some threshold (I think default £2)

text: Thanks Mo and Alex. I'll look into these

elements.text: Thanks Mo and Alex. I'll look into these

text: I'm logged into the website. I'm not requesting virtual prices through the API (<https://support.developer.betfair.com/hc/en-us/articles/115003878512-Why-are-the-prices-displayed-on-the-website-different-from-what-I-see-in-my-API-application->) but I don't really understand how this  would mean that I see more favourable prices on the website. I would expect the opposite: I'm receiving a subset of prices through the API, shouldn't that mean that the range of available prices on the website is at least as wide?

attachments.title: Why are the prices displayed on the website different from what I see in my API application?
attachments.text: The Betfair Sports Exchange tries to match bets against the bets placed by other users as well as equivalent bets where possible. These "virtual" bets follow the rules for cross-matching ...
attachments.fallback: Betfair Developer Program: Why are the prices displayed on the website different from what I see in my API application?

) but I don't really understand how this  would mean that I see more favourable prices on the website. I would expect the opposite: I'm receiving a subset of prices through the API, shouldn't that mean that the range of available prices on the website is at least as wide?

text: refresh rate is set to 1 sec which is similar to the speed of requests that I'm making and betview is set to £2, so most granular, as I understand it
